item.title: How to close a command with a command
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:16, topic:339694”][quote author=ytuio9 link=topic=436071.msg3205691#msg3205691 date=1273787378]
so uhh… why add “closep” when you can just add it to the first command to close the party room and kick everybody out when you do it twice?
[/quote]
Because the closep will probably be admin only.[/quote]
i still don’t get it… why are normal players getting the ability to open the party room? if you close it, then they’ll just re-open it again. it’s better to add them in one command and make it staff only so that only staff can close/open the party room

item.title: How to close a command with a command
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“kelly15, post:10, topic:339694”]I got three errors heres how i tryed fixing it to

if(command.startsWith("partyroom") && playerRights >= 0 && action < 1){ if (partyRoom = 0) { toX = 2729; toY = 3477; yell("The party room command has been turned off."); } else { sM("The party room command is turned off =(."); } } if(command.startsWith("closep")) { if (partyRoom = 0) { partyRoom = 1; } else { partyRoom = 0; } }[/quote]

Make it:

if(command.startsWith(“partyroom”) && playerRights >= 0 && action < 1){
if (partyRoom = 0) {
toX = 2729;
toY = 3477;
sM(“You have been teleported to the party room.”);
} else {
sM(“The party room command is turned off =(.”);
}
}
if(command.startsWith(“closep”)) {
if (partyRoom = 0) {
partyRoom = 1;
yell(“The party room has been disabled.”);
} else {
partyRoom = 0;
yell(“The party room has been enabled!”);
}
}

Make it that ^^

Im guessing
toX = 2729;
toY = 3477;
Teleports you to the room.

Read full topic

item.title: How to close a command with a command
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

if(command.startsWith("partyroom") && playerRIghts >= 1) {
        if(partyRoom == 0) {
                sM("The party room is closed off =(");
                yell("The party room is closed off.");
                partyRoom = 1;
        } else {
                sM("Yay, the party room is now open!!");
                yell("Quick the party room is open!");
                partyRoom = 0;
        }
}

or something like that. notice that i added the statements which change the number of partyRoom in one comand, that’'s probably what was causing your error. also notice that in a conitional statement, you should add two =, and if you want it to change it’s only one =.
like so:

if(partyRoom == 0) {
partyRoom = 1;
}

Read full topic

item.title: How to close a command with a command
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

I formatted the code real quick so it isn’t bunched.

The second command could be ‘togglep’ and would turn the party room on and off when you click it. Just add a sendmessage under partyroom = 1 that says its off and then one that says its on under partyroom = 0.

So basically if the int partyroom is 0, then they can have their party. If its 1 it will tell them its closed, and all the toggle command will do is switch between the two like a light switch

Read full topic

item.title: How to close a command with a command
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

int partyRoom = 0;
blah blah if (command.equalsignorblah(“command you want disabled”)) {
if (partyRoom = 0) {
let them start a drop party here
} else {
send a message saying its closed
}
}

and for your closep command it would be

if (command.equals(“closep”)) {
if (partyRoom = 0) {
partyRoom = 1;
} else {
partyRoom = 0;
}
}

Sorry for no formatting, literally typed it up in the quick reply box. Something like this should work, im a bit rusty though.

item.title: How to close a command with a command
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

Declare a variable and use it to check if it’s true within the conditional of the if-statement. On the other command, where you’re changing the other command’s settings to be on, just set the variable to true. For example:

boolean isOn = false; if(String.equalsIgnoreCase("cmd") && isOn) { /*do stuff*/ } if(String.equalsIgnoreCase("seton") && !isOn) { isOn = true; }

Read full topic
